gw.api.webservice.cc.financials

Class ClaimFinancialsAPIImpl

  • java.lang.Object
    • gw.api.webservice.cc.financials.ClaimFinancialsAPIImpl

  • public class ClaimFinancialsAPIImpl
extends java.lang.Object
    The Claim Financials API provides methods for importing claim financials data when the system is using the "Financials View" integration mode and for updating the status of a requested check when the system is using the "Financials Entry" integration mode.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors

      ClaimFinancialsAPIImpl()
      Default constructor

    • Method Detail

      • addClaimFinancials

        public java.lang.String addClaimFinancials(TransactionSet transactionSet)
                                    throws DataConversionException,
                                           EntityStateException
        Imports financial data for a single claim. This API should be used only when financials entry happens outside ClaimCenter.

        Only transaction sets with status "approved" are allowed to be imported.

        All transactions in the transaction set must have a status of "submitted", "pendingvoid", "voided", "pendingstop", "stopped", or "recoded".

        All checks in the in the transaction set must have a status of "requested", "pendingvoid", "voided", "pendingstop", "stopped", "issued", or "cleared".

        Parameters:
        transactionSet - A set of financial transactions for a single claim; all of the transactions must have the same currency
        Returns:
        An identifier for the imported transaction set.
        Throws:
        DataConversionException - Thrown if there's a problem in the imported data; for example, a bad typecode or missing required field.
        EntityStateException - Thrown if there's a transaction or check with an invalid status in in the transaction set.

      • addClaimFinancials

        public java.lang.String addClaimFinancials(TransactionSet transactionSet,
                                           java.math.BigDecimal exchangeRate,
                                           java.lang.String exchangeRateDescription)
                                    throws DataConversionException,
                                           EntityStateException
        Imports financial data for a single claim. This API should be used only when financials entry happens outside ClaimCenter.

        Only transaction sets with status "approved" are allowed to be imported.

        All transactions in the transaction set must have a status of "submitted", "pendingvoid", "voided", "pendingstop", "stopped", or "recoded".

        All checks in the in the transaction set must have a status of "requested", "pendingvoid", "voided", "pendingstop", "stopped", "issued", or "cleared".

        Parameters:
        transactionSet - A set of financial transactions for a single claim; all of the transactions must have the same currency
        exchangeRate - exchange rate from the transaction currency to the claim currency, for which a "custom" exchange rate entity will be created and set on the Transactions; the amount values for each transaction are not recalculated using this rate, so it is quite possible to add Transactions through this method with amount ratios that do not match the exchange rate (a warning will be logged in this case); if this argument is null, no exchange rates will be applied to the Transactions
        exchangeRateDescription - exchange rate description, can be null
        Returns:
        An identifier for the imported transaction set.
        Throws:
        DataConversionException - Thrown if there's a problem in the imported data; for example, a bad typecode or missing required field.
        EntityStateException - Thrown if there's a transaction or check with an invalid status in in the transaction set.

      • addClaimFinancials

        public java.lang.String addClaimFinancials(TransactionSet transactionSet,
                                           java.math.BigDecimal exchangeRate,
                                           java.lang.String exchangeRateDescription,
                                           boolean commit)
                                    throws DataConversionException,
                                           EntityStateException
        Imports financial data for a single claim. This API should be used only when financials entry happens outside ClaimCenter.

        Only transaction sets with status "approved" are allowed to be imported.

        All transactions in the transaction set must have a status of "submitted", "pendingvoid", "voided", "pendingstop", "stopped", or "recoded".

        All checks in the in the transaction set must have a status of "requested", "pendingvoid", "voided", "pendingstop", "stopped", "issued", or "cleared".

        Parameters:
        transactionSet - A set of financial transactions for a single claim; all of the transactions must have the same currency
        exchangeRate - exchange rate from the transaction currency to the claim currency, for which a "custom" exchange rate entity will be created and set on the Transactions; the amount values for each transaction are not recalculated using this rate, so it is quite possible to add Transactions through this method with amount ratios that do not match the exchange rate (a warning will be logged in this case); if this argument is null, no exchange rates will be applied to the Transactions
        exchangeRateDescription - exchange rate description, can be null
        Returns:
        An identifier for the imported transaction set.
        Throws:
        DataConversionException - Thrown if there's a problem in the imported data; for example, a bad typecode or missing required field.
        EntityStateException - Thrown if there's a transaction or check with an invalid status in in the transaction set.

      • addClaimFinancialsWithValidation

        public TransactionSetApprovalResult addClaimFinancialsWithValidation(TransactionSet transactionSetData,
                                                                     boolean checkForDuplicateChecks)
                                                              throws DataConversionException,
                                                                     PermissionException
        Imports a single TransactionSet for a claim. Unlike addClaimFinancials(TransactionSetData), this method will run validation rules on the data, submit it for approval, and fire Transaction Post-Setup rules after the data is approved.

        This method should be used as a means to import financial data in an automated way as it runs the imported data through the same steps transactions which are set up in the UI are run through.

        Parameters:
        transactionSetData - A set of financial transactions for a single claim; all of the transactions must have the same currency
        checkForDuplicateChecks - If true, this method will check for duplicate checks when importing a checkset.
        Returns:
        A validation result that holds one of three results:
          ValidationFailed - this result will contain a list of validation errors
          ValidButUnapproved - this result will contain the String of the imported TransactionSet and a list of reasons for approval
          ValidAndApproved - this result will contain the String of the imported TransactionSet
        Throws:
        DataConversionException - Thrown if there is a problem in the imported data; Also thrown if the imported transaction fails the parameters AllowMultilineTransactions and AllowMultiplePayments
        PermissionException - Thrown if the calling user doesn't have permission to perform the operation. Also thrown if approval adapter determines that the requesting user has no authority to import the TransactionSet.

      • addClaimFinancialsWithValidation

        public TransactionSetApprovalResult addClaimFinancialsWithValidation(TransactionSet transactionSetData,
                                                                     boolean checkForDuplicateChecks,
                                                                     java.math.BigDecimal exchangeRate,
                                                                     java.lang.String exchangeRateDescription)
                                                              throws DataConversionException,
                                                                     PermissionException
        Imports a single TransactionSet for a claim. Unlike addClaimFinancials(TransactionSetData), this method will run validation rules on the data, submit it for approval, and fire Transaction Post-Setup rules after the data is approved.

        This method should be used as a means to import financial data in an automated way as it runs the imported data through the same steps transactions which are set up in the UI are run through.

        Parameters:
        transactionSetData - A set of financial transactions for a single claim; all of the transactions must have the same currency
        checkForDuplicateChecks - if true, this method will check for duplicate checks when importing a checkset
        exchangeRate - exchange rate from the transaction currency to the reserving currency, for which a "custom" exchange rate entity will be created and set on the Transactions; the amount values for each transaction are not recalculated using this rate, so it is quite possible to add Transactions through this method with amount ratios that do not match the exchange rate (a warning will be logged in this case); if this argument is null, no exchange rates will be applied to the Transactions
        exchangeRateDescription - exchange rate description, can be null
        Returns:
        A validation result that holds one of three results:
          ValidationFailed - this result will contain a list of validation errors
          ValidButUnapproved - this result will contain the String of the imported TransactionSet and a list of reasons for approval
          ValidAndApproved - this result will contain the String of the imported TransactionSet
        Throws:
        DataConversionException - Thrown if there is a problem in the imported data; Also thrown if the imported transaction fails the parameters AllowMultilineTransactions and AllowMultiplePayments
        PermissionException - Thrown if the calling user doesn't have permission to perform the operation. Also thrown if approval adapter determines that the requesting user has no authority to import the TransactionSet.

      • verifyPaymentExceedsReservesParameterObeyed

        public void verifyPaymentExceedsReservesParameterObeyed(CheckSet checkSet)
        Throws:
        com.guidewire.pl.system.webservices.XMLFieldConversionException - if the AllowPaymentsExceedReservesLimits parameter is false and any of the non-supplemental, non first-and-final, draft payments of the (non-manual) checks in this CheckSet exceed the available reserves for its exposure/CostType/CostCategory.

      • findAndSetReserveLine

        public void findAndSetReserveLine(Transaction transaction)
        Determines the proper ReserveLine for this Transaction and sets it into the Transaction. If an existing ReserveLine is a match, then this ReserveLine is used. Otherwise, a new ReserveLine is created and used. If this Transaction already has a non-null Reserveline and it is not in 'New' or 'Draft' LifeCycleState, then this method has no effect (i.e., you cannot change the ReserveLine of a Transaction once it has been permanently saved to the database).

        After setting the ReserveLine, also transitions the Transaction to a new valid LifeCycleState, based on its current state.

        Note: This method should only be called on a new Transaction.

        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if this Transaction is not new
        java.lang.AssertionError - if there is no new LifeCycleState available for transitioning to, from the current state of the Transaction.

      • updateCheckStatus

        public void updateCheckStatus(java.lang.String checkID,
                              java.lang.String checkNumber,
                              java.util.Calendar issueDate,
                              TransactionStatus status,
                              FieldValue[] extensions)
                       throws EntityStateException
        Updates the status of a check that has been requested by a user in ClaimCenter. For example, this API should be invoked when the status of the check changes from "requested" to "issued". This should be used only when financials entry happens in ClaimCenter.

        Allowed check status are "issued", "cleared", "voided", and "stopped". The "Issued" and "Cleared" statuses are not legal options if this check is part of a multi-payee check group that has been voided or stopped.

        If the check status is changed to "voided" or "stopped", the status on the payments are updated to this, as well.

        checkNumber and issueDate is used when updating the check status to "issued". For other updates, these two fields can be left as NULL.

        Note that if the check is pending stop or pending void and the new status is issued or cleared, the statuses of the check and its payments are updated and a warning activity is created and assigned to the user who attempted to void or stop the check so that the user knows that the check was not voided.

        Parameters:
        checkID - Identifier of the check to be updated.
        checkNumber - Number of the check. Optional; use NULL if not updating.
        issueDate - Date the check was issued. Optional, use NULL if not updating.
        status - Status of the check. Required; cannot be NULL.
        extensions - Set of name/value pairs of extension fields to update on the check. Can be NULL if no extension fields to update.
        Throws:
        EntityStateException - Thrown if the new check status is invalid.

      • loadCheckByPublicID

        public Check loadCheckByPublicID(java.lang.String checkPublicID,
                                 Bundle bundle)
        Loads the check identified by checkPublicId and returns it in a new writable bundle
        Parameters:
        checkPublicID - check's public id
        bundle - bundle to add check
        Returns:
        check after it is added to the bundle

      • applyForeignExchangeAdjustmentToCheck

        public void applyForeignExchangeAdjustmentToCheck(java.lang.String checkId,
                                                  java.math.BigDecimal newClaimAmount,
                                                  java.math.BigDecimal newReportingAmount)
                                           throws EntityStateException
        Adjusts this check's claim and/or reporting amounts to the specified values. Such adjustments are intended for cases where better values for the amounts are determined later, after the check is created and escalated. For example, if a check is written from a claim-currency bank account, the amount actually deducted from that account's balance will be determined by exchange rates in effect at the time the check clears. This method allows, for example, the claim amounts of the payments to be adjusted to reflect that amount for which the check actually cleared. Null may be passed for newClaimAmount or newReportingAmount, in which case no adjustment is made to that amount. Adjustments are distributed proportionally among the payment's line items. For example, if the payment has four line items with claim amounts of $40, $20, $10, and $10 (a total of $80), and newClaimAmount is $100, then the claim amounts will be adjused to $50, $25, $12.50, and $12.50. In this example, each claim amount was increased by 25% (equal to the total relative increase), and each new claim amount comprises the same fraction of the total as it did before the adjustment. Adjustments to the claim and reporting amounts are largely independent. When this method is called, the system must be configured in multicurrency mode and the check must:
        • have already been escalated and sent downstream but not been canceled or transferred
        • not be part of a multi-payee (grouped) check
        Foreign exchange adjustments only affect total incurred and total paid calculations. They do not further erode reserves.
        Parameters:
        checkId - the publicID of the check whose payment(s) are to receive the foreign exchange adjustment
        newClaimAmount - the value to which this check's claim amount should be adjusted; if null, the claim amount is not adjusted
        newReportingAmount - the value to which this check's reporting amount should be adjusted; if null, the reporting amount is not adjusted
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if there is a conflict between the new, adjusted amounts and the currencies: if newClaimAmount is different from the current transaction amount and the transaction and claim currencies are the same, or if newClaimAmount is different from newReportingAmount and the reporting and claim currencies are the same, or if newReportingAmount is different from the current transaction amount and the reporting and transaction currencies are the same
        EntityStateException - if the check has an invalid status (something other than Requesting, Requested, Issued or Cleared) or is not valid for receiving a foreign exchange adjustment according to the criteria listed above.

      • applyForeignExchangeAdjustmentToCheck

        public void applyForeignExchangeAdjustmentToCheck(java.lang.String checkId,
                                                  java.math.BigDecimal newClaimAmount)
                                           throws EntityStateException
        Adjusts this check's claim and/or reporting amounts to the specified values. Such adjustments are intended for cases where better values for the amounts are determined later, after the check is created and escalated. For example, if a check is written from a claim-currency bank account, the amount actually deducted from that account's balance will be determined by exchange rates in effect at the time the check clears. This method allows, for example, the claim amounts of the payments to be adjusted to reflect that amount for which the check actually cleared.Adjustments are distributed proportionally among the payment's line items. For example, if the payment has four line items with claim amounts of $40, $20, $10, and $10 (a total of $80), and newClaimAmount is $100, then the claim amounts will be adjused to $50, $25, $12.50, and $12.50. In this example, each claim amount was increased by 25% (equal to the total relative increase), and each new claim amount comprises the same fraction of the total as it did before the adjustment. In this variant of the method, only a claim amount is specified, and an adjustment to the reporting amount is selected automatically. For example, if the reporting currency equals the transaction currency, then the reporting amount is not adjusted. If the payment's claim is in the reporting currency, then the reporting amount is adjusted to newClaimAmount. Otherwise, the adjusted reporting amount is determined by converting newClaimAmount to the reporting currency using this payment's claim-to-reporting exchange rate. When this method is called, the system must be configured in multicurrency mode and the check must:
        • have already been escalated and sent downstream but not been canceled or transferred
        • not be part of a multi-payee (grouped) check
        Foreign exchange adjustments only affect total incurred and total paid calculations. They do not further erode reserves.
        Parameters:
        checkId - the publicID of the check whose payment(s) are to receive the foreign exchange adjustment
        newClaimAmount - the adjusted amount for this payment in the claim currency; cannot be null
        Throws:
        EntityStateException - if the check has an invalid status (something other than Requesting, Requested, Issued or Cleared) or is not valid for receiving a foreign exchange adjustment according to the criteria listed above.
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if claim amount is being adjusted but the transaction currency equals the claim currency

      • applyForeignExchangeAdjustmentToPayment

        public void applyForeignExchangeAdjustmentToPayment(java.lang.String paymentId,
                                                    java.math.BigDecimal newClaimAmount,
                                                    java.math.BigDecimal newReportingAmount)
                                             throws EntityStateException
        Adjusts this payment's claim and/or reporting amounts to the specified values. Such adjustments are intended for cases where better values for the amounts are determined later, after the check is created and escalated. For example, if a check is written from a claim-currency bank account, the amount actually deducted from that account's balance will be determined by exchange rates in effect at the time the check clears. This method allows, for example, the claim amount of the payment to be adjusted to reflect that amount for which the check actually cleared. Null may be passed for newClaimAmount or newReportingAmount, in which case no adjustment is made to that amount. Adjustments are distributed proportionally among the payment's line items. For example, if the payment has four line items with claim amounts of $40, $20, $10, and $10 (a total of $80), and newClaimAmount is $100, then the claim amounts will be adjused to $50, $25, $12.50, and $12.50. In this example, each claim amount was increased by 25% (equal to the total relative increase), and each new claim amount comprises the same fraction of the total as it did before the adjustment. Adjustments to the claim and reporting amounts are largely independent. When this method is called, the system must be configured in multicurrency mode and the payment must:
        • be on a check that has already been escalated and sent downstream but not been canceled or transferred
        • not have been recoded
        • not be an offset payment
        • not be part of a multi-payee (grouped) check
        Foreign exchange adjustments only affect total incurred and total paid calculations. They do not further erode reserves.
        Parameters:
        paymentId - the PublicID of the payment to receive the foreign exchange adjustment
        newClaimAmount - the value to which this payment's claim amount should be adjusted; if null, the claim amount is not adjusted
        newReportingAmount - the value to which this payment's reporting amount should be adjusted; if null, the reporting amount is not adjusted
        Throws:
        EntityStateException - if the payment is not valid for receiving a foreign exchange adjustment (according to the criteria listed above)
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if there is a conflict between the new, adjusted amounts and the currencies: if newClaimAmount is different from the current transaction amount and the transaction and claim currencies are the same, or if newClaimAmount is different from newReportingAmount and the reporting and claim currencies are the same, or if newReportingAmount is different from the current transaction amount and the reporting and transaction currencies are the same

      • applyForeignExchangeAdjustmentToPayment

        public void applyForeignExchangeAdjustmentToPayment(java.lang.String paymentId,
                                                    java.math.BigDecimal newClaimAmount)
                                             throws EntityStateException
        Adjusts this payment's claim and/or reporting amounts to the specified values. Such adjustments are intended for cases where better values for the amounts are determined later, after the check is created and escalated. For example, if a check is written from a claim-currency bank account, the amount actually deducted from that account's balance will be determined by exchange rates in effect at the time the check clears. This method allows, for example, the claim amount of the payment to be adjusted to reflect that amount for which the check actually cleared.Adjustments are distributed proportionally among the payment's line items. For example, if the payment has four line items with claim amounts of $40, $20, $10, and $10 (a total of $80), and newClaimAmount is $100, then the claim amounts will be adjused to $50, $25, $12.50, and $12.50. In this example, each claim amount was increased by 25% (equal to the total relative increase), and each new claim amount comprises the same fraction of the total as it did before the adjustment. In this variant of the method, only a claim amount is specified, and an adjustment to the reporting amount is selected automatically. For example, if the reporting currency equals the transaction currency, then the reporting amount is not adjusted. If the payment's claim is in the reporting currency, then the reporting amount is adjusted to newClaimAmount. Otherwise, the adjusted reporting amount is determined by converting newClaimAmount to the reporting currency using this payment's claim-to-reporting exchange rate. When this method is called, the system must be configured in multicurrency mode and the payment must:
        • be on a check that has already been escalated and sent downstream but not been canceled or transferred
        • not have been recoded
        • not be an offset payment
        • not be part of a multi-payee (grouped) check
        Foreign exchange adjustments only affect total incurred and total paid calculations. They do not further erode reserves.
        Parameters:
        paymentId - the publicID of the payment to receive the foreign exchange adjustment
        newClaimAmount - the adjusted amount for this payment in the claim currency; cannot be null
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if claim amount is being adjusted but the transaction currency equals the claim currency
        EntityStateException - if the payment is not valid for receiving a foreign exchange adjustment (according to the criteria listed above).

      • denyRecovery

        public void denyRecovery(java.lang.String recoveryId)
                  throws SOAPException
        API for performing a downstream denial of the recovery transaction. A denied recovery can be resubmitted as is, deleted, or left in denied state.
        Parameters:
        recoveryId - the publicID of the recovery to be denied
        Throws:
        SOAPException - Thrown if an unexpected error occurs on the server while updating the recovery.

      • denyCheck

        public void denyCheck(java.lang.String checkId)
               throws SOAPException
        API for performing a downstream denial of the checks. A denied check can be resubmitted as is, deleted, or left in denied state. Important Note: Only single payee checks can be denied
        Parameters:
        checkId - the publicID of the check to be denied
        Throws:
        SOAPException - Thrown if an unexpected error occurs on the server while updating the check.
        EntityStateException - if the check cannot be denied (for example, if its status is not TransactionStatus.TC_SUBMITTING or TransactionStatus.TC_SUBMITTED)

      • getClaimAmounts

        public CurrencyAmount[] getClaimAmounts(java.lang.String[] claimNumbers,
                                        FinancialsCalculationType financialsCalculationType,
                                        CostCategory costCategory,
                                        CostType costType)
                                 throws SOAPSenderException,
                                        SOAPServerException
        Fetches financials information for a set of claims (designated by claim number) and based on a given financials calculation type, cost type, and cost category. Note that not all financials values map to a specific cost category or cost type, so if you need the overall information for a claim those parameters should be left null.
        Parameters:
        claimNumbers - The numbers for all the claims that financials values are being requested for.
        financialsCalculationType - The type of the financials calculation for this request.
        costCategory - The cost category of the desired financials values. If this is null, it will be ignored in the request.
        costType - The cost type of the desired financials values. If this is null, it will be ignored in the request.
        Returns:
        The array of requested financials values. The returned values are in the same order as the claims that were passed in through the claimNumbers parameter.
        Throws:
        SOAPSenderException - If either claimNumbers or FinancialsCalculationType are null.
        SOAPServerException - If the calculation associated with the passed FinancialsCalculationType cannot be found.

      • getExposureAmounts

        public CurrencyAmount[] getExposureAmounts(java.lang.String[] exposureIDs,
                                           FinancialsCalculationType financialsCalculationType,
                                           CostCategory costCategory,
                                           CostType costType)
                                    throws SOAPSenderException,
                                           SOAPServerException
        Fetches financials information for a set of exposures (designated by public id) and based on a given financials calculation type, cost type, and cost category. Note that not all financials values map to a specific cost category or cost type, so if you need the overall information for an exposure those parameters should be left null.
        Parameters:
        exposureIDs - The public ids for all the exposures that financials values are being requested for.
        financialsCalculationType - The type of the financials calculation for this request.
        costCategory - The cost category of the desired financials values. If this is null, it will be ignored in the request.
        costType - The cost type of the desired financials values. If this is null, it will be ignored in the request.
        Returns:
        The array of requested financials values. The returned values are in the same order as the exposures that were passed in through the exposureIDs parameter.
        Throws:
        SOAPSenderException - If either exposureIDs or FinancialsCalculationType are null.
        SOAPServerException - If the calculation associated with the passed FinancialsCalculationType cannot be found.

      • validateAvailableReservesNotNegative

        public void validateAvailableReservesNotNegative(TransactionSet transactionSet)
                                          throws com.guidewire.pl.system.webservices.XMLDataConversionException
        Throws:
        com.guidewire.pl.system.webservices.XMLDataConversionException - if any of the ReserveLines associated with the specified TransactionSet will result in negative available reserves.

      • validateImportedTransaction

        public void validateImportedTransaction(Transaction transaction)
                                 throws com.guidewire.pl.system.webservices.XMLDataConversionException,
                                        EntityStateException
        Throws:
        com.guidewire.pl.system.webservices.XMLDataConversionException - if the AllowMultipleLineItems config param is set to false, and the Transaction has multiple line items present on it.
        EntityStateException - if the Transaction being imported is either a retired one or one that needs to be submitted. In other words, if the Transaction's Status is not one of "Submitted, Pending Void, Voided, Pending Stop, Stopped, or Recoded."

      • validateImportedCheck

        public void validateImportedCheck(Check check)
                           throws com.guidewire.pl.system.webservices.XMLDataConversionException,
                                  EntityStateException
        Throws:
        com.guidewire.pl.system.webservices.XMLDataConversionException - if the AllowMultiplePayments config param is set to false, and the Check has multiple payments present on it.
        com.guidewire.pl.system.webservices.XMLFieldConversionException - if the Check doesn't have at least one Payee set on it.
        EntityStateException - if the Check being imported is either a retired one or one that needs to be submitted. In other words, if the Check's Status is not one of "Requested, Pending Void, Voided, Pending Stop, Stopped, Issued, or Cleared."

      • validateAllowMultiplePayments

        public void validateAllowMultiplePayments(Check check)
                                   throws com.guidewire.pl.system.webservices.XMLDataConversionException
        Throws:
        com.guidewire.pl.system.webservices.XMLDataConversionException - if the AllowMultiplePayments config param is set to false, and the Check has multiple payments present on it.

      • createApprovalActivity

        public Activity createApprovalActivity(CheckSet checkSet,
                                       java.lang.String[] approvalIssues)
        Parameters:
        checkSet - checkset to create approval activity
        approvalIssues - the isuse to create
        Returns:
        An approval activity for the given CheckSet and assigns it.

      • getFinancialsCalculation

        public FinancialsCalculation getFinancialsCalculation(FinancialsCalculationType type)
        Retrieves the financials calculation corresponding to the passed financials calculation type. This method will also lazy-load the financials calculation map if it has not been populated yet.
        Parameters:
        type - the calculation type
        Returns:
        The financials calculation corresponding to the passed financials calculation type.
